proposals.reasoning: This team has broad consensus across the table and keeps the early loud drivers (like Eve and myself) off Mission 1 so our talk can later be compared to actual results. Starting with Alice–Grace–Iris gives us a low-drama, information-rich first mission: if it passes cleanly, we get a solid baseline of likely-good players; if it fails, the blame is tightly contained within a single well-discussed trio, making the analysis straightforward. Grace and Iris have both been relatively measured, and Alice is a central pick in most suggested lineups, so this composition best matches the emerging group logic while maximizing clarity from Mission 1’s outcome.

votes.comment: I know I’m good, and starting with a broadly supported, low-conflict trio like Alice–Grace–Iris gives us clean early info with minimal risk.
Broad consensus and low-drama first mission; rejecting now would draw needless attention without any inside info on alignments.
Early low-drama team with broad consensus; we need a clean info baseline and there’s no strong reason yet to distrust any of Alice, Grace, or Iris specifically.
Broad consensus, no strong individual red flags yet, and Mission 1 is low-risk and high-info with a tightly scoped trio.
Broad consensus early team with no known evil teammates; rejecting would be suspicious without a strong reason.
Broad consensus, low-drama info-rich first mission; no one on the team is pinging strongly evil yet and we need an early baseline.
No known red flags on this lineup yet, and a quiet-leaning first team should give clean info if it somehow fails.
Matches my earlier support for a low-drama Alice–Grace–Iris start and gives us a clean information baseline either way.
I’m on the team with two broadly townread, non-pushy picks; Mission 1 info will be very clean whether it passes or fails.
Matches broad table consensus and keeps higher-profile players (including me) off the first mission, which is a safe, low-information-risk start for me to support.

discussion.content: Early on I’d rather lean toward people who aren’t rushing to steer the conversation, so I’m tentatively okay with including quieter players like Grace or Iris, plus one of Bob/Charlie if they don’t act too pushy about it. Let’s avoid anyone who’s already heavily trying to control the first team.

I like the idea of starting with quieter players too, so something like Grace, Iris, and maybe Alice herself feels like a reasonable first team. I’d rather avoid stacking it with people who are already driving the discussion a lot this early.

I’m fine starting with a quieter-heavy team like Grace, Iris, and Alice, as long as we don’t completely ignore someone like Henry for early missions either, since keeping all our info-holders off the board can backfire later.

I’m okay starting with a Grace–Iris–Alice team, but I’d like at least one of them to explain their own preferences a bit first so we’re not just handing the first mission to the quietest corner of the table.

I like the quieter-leaning idea, but I’d rather not have a team of three people who’ve barely been questioned yet. Something like Alice, Grace, and me feels like a better balance between someone who’s talked a bit and a couple of lower-profile picks.
I’m wary of how fast Eve volunteered herself there, so I’d rather see something like Alice, Grace, and Iris for the first team, with the understanding we reshuffle hard if it fails.

I’m comfortable starting with something like Alice–Iris–me, especially since there’s already a lot of talk around that combo and we’ll get a clean data point if it passes or fails. Eve putting herself forward this early makes me a bit hesitant to include her on the very first mission.

Alice–Grace–Iris feels like a solid low-drama first team to me, and if it somehow fails we get a really clear cluster to scrutinize. I’d rather keep people who pushed hardest for shaping the early narrative, like Eve or even Charlie, off Mission 1 so we can compare their talk to actual results later.

Given how much agreement there already is, I’m okay with an Alice–Grace–me team for Mission 1, mainly because it keeps the early loud voices like Eve off the board so we can compare what they’ve been saying to actual results later. If this first mission fails, we’ll have a very tight trio to dissect instead of a muddled mix.

I’m fine with the Alice–Grace–Iris team for Mission 1 since it lines up with most people’s thinking and keeps the early drivers like Eve off the board for now. If it passes cleanly, that gives us a decent baseline to compare future teams against.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1’s team of Alice–Grace–Iris was completely clean, so they’re our strongest provisional core. Nearly everyone has expressed comfort with that trio staying together, and multiple players (Bob, Eve, Frank, Grace, Henry, Iris) have specifically highlighted adding me (Diana) as the preferred fourth over riskier or more controversial picks like Henry. This lineup both maximizes the probability of a second clean mission and gives the table a clear, low‑drama data point: if this team passes and succeeds, it strongly town‑leans all four; if it passes and fails, it tightly narrows where the evil is hiding among a well‑discussed group rather than spreading uncertainty across fresh, less‑vetted names.

votes.comment: Same clean core from Mission 1 plus widely townread Diana; best chance for a second success and good info either way.
This locks in the same clean core plus a widely trusted fourth, risking a second consecutive success with no new info or leverage for evil.
First mission’s Alice–Grace–Iris core is clean so far, and adding widely trusted Diana is a low‑risk way to push for a second success while keeping scrutiny on a well‑discussed group.
Keeps the fully clean core from Mission 1 and adds me, which most players already favored; best balance of safety and information right now.
No evil is on this team, so as evil I need to keep it from going through to avoid another likely clean success for good.
Consistent with the clean Mission 1 core and my prior preference for adding Diana; good balance of safety and information gain.
Keeps the fully clean core from Mission 1 and adds a widely town-leaned fourth, maximizing odds of a second success while giving strong info either way.
All four are widely townread and none of my known evil teammates are on it; too likely to be a clean good team and put us down 0–2.
Keeps the fully clean core from Mission 1 and adds a widely supported fourth (Diana), maximizing both success odds and useful info from the result.

I’d rather not double down on the exact same core plus the most consensus fourth; this feels too safe and low‑information. I’d prefer swapping in someone like Eve or Bob to diversify and actually test a wider pool before we lock in a bloc.

discussion.content: Given Mission 1 went clean with me, Grace, and Iris, I’m inclined to keep at least two of us on the next team for consistency. Obviously a spy could have passed, but until we see any fails, Grace and Iris look like our best bets.
Keeping a core from the first clean team makes sense, but I’d like to see at least one new face added so we actually learn something—maybe Alice, Grace, Iris plus one of Charlie or Diana?

I like keeping a solid core from the first mission, so I’m happy with Grace and Iris staying on, and between the new faces I slightly prefer adding Henry over Diana or Bob for now. That gives us some continuity plus one fresh read without changing too much at once.

I’m good keeping a core from the first mission, but I’d rather see something like Alice–Grace–Iris plus one of me or Bob than jumping straight to Henry, since Charlie pushing Henry in this early without any info pings me a bit.

I’m with Diana that Charlie’s early push for Henry feels a bit premature, so I’d rather see us stick with the clean core of Alice–Grace–Iris and add either Bob or Diana this round. That keeps most of what worked while giving us one new data point without jumping to someone already being subtly shielded.

I really like sticking with the Alice–Grace–Iris core for now, and I’d lean toward adding Diana over Henry since Charlie’s early push for Henry feels a bit like soft-covering. Bob’s also fine as the fourth, but I’m most comfortable with Alice–Grace–Iris–Diana this round.

I like sticking with the Alice–Grace–Iris core for now, and of the suggested additions I’m most comfortable with Diana since the early enthusiasm for Henry feels a bit rushed. I’d rather avoid piling too many untested or subtly shielded players onto the same team this early.

Keeping Alice–Grace–Iris as a core seems reasonable, but given how much heat there already is around Charlie floating my name, I’d rather see a lower‑drama fourth like Bob or Diana than double down on that.
I’m happy to keep the Alice–Grace–Iris core since the first mission was clean, and of the options I slightly prefer adding Diana here, given how odd Charlie’s early push for Henry felt.
Sticking with the Alice–Grace–Iris core seems fine to me, but I’d actually like to see Eve as the fourth since she’s been measured and not hard‑pushing any particular agenda so far.

proposals.reasoning: The Alice–Grace–Iris core has been clean on both previous missions, and a clear majority of the table wants to keep that core together. The main point of debate has been whether to rerun Diana or to swap the fourth slot to gain new information. Several players (Bob, Frank, Henry, Jack, and I) explicitly supported the 'keep the core, change the fringe' approach, with Henry often named as a good test candidate. Proposing Alice, Grace, Iris, and Henry respects the proven core, aligns with the expressed preference to avoid autopiloting the exact same four, and gives us meaningful new info on a widely suggested fourth without disrupting the most trusted trio.

votes.comment: We only need one more success, so I’d rather rerun the already clean Alice–Grace–Iris–Diana team than introduce the new risk of Henry just for information.
Consistent with my earlier stance: keep the proven core but swap the fringe to gain info on Henry rather than autopiloting the exact same four.

Grace has a strong track record from two clean missions, but Henry is untested and, from my perspective, could very well be evil. Adding him here unnecessarily risks contaminating what’s been a reliable core; I’d rather rerun Alice–Grace–Iris–Diana.
At 2–0 up the lowest‑risk play is rerunning the previously clean team including me; swapping in an untested Henry introduces unnecessary risk when we’re one success from winning.
Keeps the trusted core while finally testing someone new like I’d been asking for, so this balances safety with actually gaining information.
At 2–0 we should maximize win odds, not info. Re-running Alice–Grace–Iris–Diana (already clean) is safer than adding untested Henry right when evil must sabotage.
At 2–0 up I’d rather stick with the exact team that already succeeded than introduce a totally untested fourth when one fail loses us this mission.
I’m on the team, so I’d rather let this go through and control the outcome than risk a different lineup that might succeed cleanly for the win.
I prefer rerunning the exact same successful team with Diana; introducing Henry now adds unnecessary risk when we’re one clean mission from victory.
Henry is on the team and we need a fail opportunity this round.

proposals.reasoning: Two missions have succeeded with zero fails using the Alice–Grace–Iris core, and the second mission also successfully included Diana. With good already up 2–0 and needing only one more success, the highest-percentage play is to minimize new uncertainty and rerun the exact proven team rather than introduce an untested player who could be a hidden spy. Even though I previously suggested swapping the fourth slot, the objective best chance to secure the win now is to stick with the only fully tested and clean combination we have.

votes.comment: Same four already passed a mission with zero fails; at 2–0 up, rerunning the proven team is the safest path to a win.
I still don’t like auto-running the same core; if they’re all good this just hands good the game, and if there’s a deep-cover spy we learn nothing new.
We’re 2–0 with this exact core and this exact four already passed clean; introducing a new, untested player now adds more risk than rerunning the proven team for the win.
Same four have already produced a clean mission; introducing new players adds unnecessary risk when we only need one more success.
I’m still against auto-running the same four when it could be hiding a deep-cover spy; we should test at least one new person instead of repeating this exact team.
Two clean missions with the same core plus Diana make it highly likely this team is all good; introducing a new player now adds more risk than value when we only need one more success.
Same core has been clean twice and this exact four already passed once with no fails; at 2–0 up, rerunning the most proven team is the safest path to a win.
We’re one success from losing and this team has no confirmed spy; I’d rather not auto-rerun the same four and risk handing good the game without ever testing new players or getting better info.
Same core has two clean missions and Diana was on the second; rerunning the only fully tested team is the safest way to secure the win now.
No known evil is on this team while good is already up 2–0; we need a spy on the mission to have a chance, so this is too safe for good.

discussion.content: Given two clean missions with the same core, I really want to keep Alice–Grace–Iris together, and I’m tentatively okay adding Diana again unless someone has a strong reason to shake things up.

I’m a bit wary of just auto-locking in the same core three every time—if there is a deep-cover spy, that’s exactly where they’d want to sit. I’d like to see at least one swap this round, maybe test someone like Frank or Henry instead of rerunning the exact group.

Given we’re one success away from winning and the same Alice–Grace–Iris core has been clean twice (plus Diana once), I’d rather not get fancy here—I'd stick with those four again for this mission. If we start swapping now and hit a fail, we just give evil more info for free.

Given we only need one more success and the Alice–Grace–Iris core has been clean twice (including with me last time), I’m strongly in favor of rerunning the same four rather than introducing new uncertainty. Bob’s concern about a deep-cover spy is fair in theory, but changing now helps evil more than us if we accidentally add a spy.

I’m with Bob that auto-running the same core three every time is risky—if there is a deep-cover spy, we’re just handing them the win—so I’d like to see at least one change, maybe swap one of Alice/Grace/Iris for someone like Henry or Frank to actually test new people.

I really want to keep the Alice–Grace–Iris core since they’ve been clean twice, but I’d rather swap the fourth slot—either test me or Henry instead of just auto-adding Diana again so we actually learn something this round.

Given we’re already 2–0 up with the same core and the only change last time (adding Diana) still gave us a clean result, I’d rather not introduce new risk now—Alice, Iris, Diana, and I feels like the safest path to a 3–0. If people really hate repeating, I’d at least keep Alice–Iris together and only swap the fourth, but I think rerunning the last team is best.

I’m with the “keep the core, change the fringe” camp: I’d keep Alice–Grace–Iris together but I’d rather swap Diana out and test someone new like Frank or me this round so we’re not blindly auto-running the same exact four to a potential loss.
Given we only need one more success, I’m most comfortable just rerunning Alice–Grace–Diana–me; changing the core now feels like it adds unnecessary risk for almost no upside.

I’m in the “keep the core, change the fringe” camp too—Alice, Grace, and Iris feel as safe as we’re going to get, but I’d rather swap Diana out and try someone like Henry this round so we’re not just autopiloting the exact same four.

evil_discussion.content: I’m leaning hardest toward Grace as Merlin. She’s been on every successful mission, consistently nudged the table away from Eve and Henry without over-explaining why, and her preferences always “just happen” to line up with the actually-good-heavy teams while sounding like cautious logic instead of gut reads. Alice and Iris feel more like standard cautious goods riding the consensus Grace helped shape, rather than the ones quietly steering it.

I’m mostly with Bob on Grace as Merlin: she’s been on every successful team, consistently framed the “safe” narrative around the Alice–Grace–Iris core, and her pushes (like preferring Diana over Henry/Bob) always happened to keep us off the board without sounding like hard reads. Alice and Iris feel more like conservative followers anchored to that core, whereas Grace subtly shaped direction while sounding like she was just going with table logic, which is exactly how I’d expect Merlin to play it here.

I’m mostly on the Grace-as-Merlin train too: she quietly anchored that Alice–Grace–Iris core from the start, consistently framed it as “safe” while pushing subtle suspicion on Henry/Eve without ever needing to spell out strong reads, and her preferences kept us off missions without looking like hard vetoes. Alice and Iris read more like conservative villagers who were happy to ride the already-accepted core, whereas Grace repeatedly justified the exact team shapes that turned out to be good-heavy with just enough “cautious logic” to pass as normal town play.

I’m with you all that Grace is the best Merlin hit: from Mission 1 on she quietly anchored the Alice–Grace–Iris core, consistently framed it as the “safe info” choice, and her preference for Diana over Henry/Bob/Eve repeatedly kept us off missions without ever sounding like a hard read. Alice and Iris feel like conservative good players who trusted that core once it was socially accepted, but it was Grace who kept giving just enough “process” to nudge the table toward exactly the teams that turned out to be good-heavy.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Grace quietly anchored the Alice–Grace–Iris core from Mission 1 and consistently framed it as the safest option, while her preferences (like favoring Diana over Henry or Eve) repeatedly kept known evil players off missions without sounding like hard reads. Alice and Iris played more like conservative followers of that already-accepted core, whereas Grace subtly steered team selection with just enough logical justification to resemble Merlin protecting her information.
